Billboard的《星期五音乐指南》是本周五最重要的发行的方便指南，这是每个人今天都会谈论的关键音乐，这将在本周末及以后主导播放列表。

本周，赛琳娜·戈麦斯（Selena Gomez）和本尼·布兰科（Benny Blanco）提升了他们的爱，杰克·哈洛（Jack Harlow）和杜贾·卡特（Doja Cat）进行了爆炸，J-Hope继续前进。在下面查看本周的所有选择：

Selena Gomez＆Benny Blanco，我说我首先爱你

我说我爱你首先是共同心脏的两半之间的创造性合作，而本尼·布兰科（Benny Blanco）的声音影响在与赛琳娜·戈麦斯（Selena Gomez）的抒情传递直接交谈中。这是一个原因，为什么专辑粉艺术品是通过钥匙孔瞥见戈麦斯和布兰科的原因 -我说我爱你首先是一个亲密的瞥见，而不是大预算的奇观。在此处阅读完整的评论。

杰克·哈洛（Jack Harlow）壮举。 Doja Cat，“只是我们”

杰克·哈洛（Jack Harlow）和杜贾·猫（Doja Cat）能够探讨马特·达蒙（Matt Damon），约翰·梅耶（John Mayer）和平克·帕特内斯（Pinkpantheress）等音乐视频的部分原因，“正是我们”是因为他们俩都是顶尖的人才；他们的新合作与A-listers的能量crack啪作响，他们可以轻松地抛弃钩子和性爱，因为他们以前做了很多次。

J-Hope，“ Mona Lisa”

J-Hope越来越擅长寻找流行音乐，嘻哈音乐和R＆B：新的独奏单曲“ Mona Lisa”，找到了BTS明星，轻松地融合了类型，浸入了他的虚假中，抛弃了一些Whoa-oa-oa，使他的热情登上了他的热情，并提供了一个breezy的登记，并适合夏季的夏季戏剧，这将适合夏季的夏季。

摩根·沃伦（Morgan Wallen），“我有点疯狂”和“以防万一”

To cap off the week in which he unveiled the May release date of his album I'm the Problem , Morgan Wallen released a pair of new songs that will make its 37-song (!) track list: “I'm a Little Crazy” allows the country superstar to waxing poetic about his place in the world, “Just in Case” grows into an earnest anthem, and both tracks feature Wallen's voice dominating the mix.

乔纳斯兄弟，“爱我到天堂”

随着乔纳斯兄弟（Jonas Brothers）在北美举行了20周年之际，男孩们决定烹饪新的东西来纪念这一场合，“爱我爱上天堂”的声音量身定制了舞台，这是一个Zippy Pop-Rock Sing-Ond-sing-sing-sing-nock and Falsetto Runs和Backing Vocals，而在成千上万的人群中唱出的声音会更好。

编辑的选择：日本早餐，忧郁的黑发（和悲伤的女人）

如果2021年的禧年将米歇尔·扎纳（Michelle Zauner）变成了独立的流行明星，那么期待已久的《忧郁黑发》（＆Sad Women）的后续活动是歌手兼词曲作者的声音，而没有牺牲任何她的歌曲创作细微的细微差别。这张新专辑探索了较情绪化的领域，但通过Zauner不断吸引的镜头折射忧郁，她的声音比以往任何时候都更加自信和值得信赖。

; 1235928588 FKA树枝揭示了西北地区如何结束“ Eusexua”：“我很感激” https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/fka-twigs-how-north-west-west-west-endend-up-on-eusexua-1235928466/Hannah Dailey Fri, 21 Mar 2025 16:23:59 +0000 MusicMusic NewsDancegenre dance https://www.billboard.com/?p=1235928466 The daughter of Ye and Kim Kardashian raps in Japanese on the track "Childlike Things."

从技术上讲， FKA Twigs的“ Childlike Things”将她的专辑Eusexua上所有歌曲中最长的歌曲完成了，最后的触摸最终是西北西北部的偶然功能。

有关的

你们发行的新歌显然是迪迪和女儿西北

03/16/2025

在周四（3月20日）发布给Instagram的视频中，这位英国歌手兼作词人讲述了Kim Kardashian和Ye（以前是Kanye West ）的长子女儿如何最终出现在专辑中，该专辑于1月份下降。在英语和日语中的11岁说唱集中，在“幼稚的事物”上吐了个电子舞节，“你好，我的名字是北/从加利福尼亚到东京/耶稣/国王/赞美上帝/耶稣是唯一的真神。”

根据Twigs的说法，这一切始于她在北部的工作室里，发现自己模糊了长期以来的歌词 - “我有多音的超音速能力/像巧克力茶壶一样，融化了'em down and burn'em up up up'' - gloucestershire在她还是个孩子的时候就构成了Gloocestershire。他们最终成为了数十年来制作的曲目的基础，但她很快意识到，她需要引进一个可以匹配和增强她正在利用的“童年能量”的合作者。

Twigs在做她的一天的化妆时告诉追随者：“ [需要]具有这种坚韧的人，具有您11岁时的观点。” “然后我看到了西北的一次采访，她是如此自信。我突然想到，我很想有一个像诺斯这样的朋友可以自己说话的朋友。”

她补充说：“我当时想，'好吧，它必须向北，她必须将自己的观点贴在这首歌上。” “她来写了关于她的信仰的文章，我认为这确实很强大。”

“孩子般的事物”最终是Eusexua上的11首曲目之一，该曲目在Billboard 200上排名第24位 - 迄今为止Twigs在图表上的最高峰。诺斯以前曾与她的父亲在秃鹰1的“说话”和秃鹰2的“炸弹”上合作。

最近，青春期前出现在Ye的“寂寞道路上仍然去阳光下”，该道路还录制了说唱歌手与迪迪之间的电话交谈的录制，他们目前在等待联邦敲诈勒索，性贩运等审判的同时被监禁。 （据报道，卡戴珊（Kardashian）不同意这首歌，并在Ye发布的所谓短信中表示，她试图通过TMZ来试图通过商标North的名字来阻止发布。）

在她的视频中，Twigs结束时，观看了几十年来“童趣般的事物”如何融合在一起，从诺斯出生之前。音乐家说：“疯狂的是，我12、13岁时写了这首歌；她11岁时就写了这首歌。” “这是一项合作，已经花了数十年的时间才能实现。北部帮助这首歌在这么多年之后栩栩如生，为此，我非常感激。”

; 1235928466 在Playboi Carti的“音乐”专辑的推出策略中https://www.billboard.com/pro/playboi-carti-music-album-inside-rollout-strategy/Dan Rys Fri, 21 Mar 2025 16:22:40 +0000 BusinessManagementExecutive of the Weekgenre hiphopopium records https://www.billboard.com/?post_type = billboard_pro_post&p=1235928518 "The strategy really opened the conversation and made the fans feel like a part of the process," says Carti's manager Erin Larsen.

当Playboi Carti在3月14日凌晨发行了他期待已久的第三张专辑Music时，它遇到了潮汐浪潮 - 它的歌曲立即淹没了Daily the Daily Spotify和Apple Music流式传输图表，并立即成为Spotify在2025年一天中最受欢迎的专辑，以及2020年的第一批专辑。下周。

有关的

Playboi Carti或Chappell Roan Unseat Kendrick＆Sza在Hot 100上可以吗？

03/19/2025

这已经很长时间了，球迷们当然已经准备好了。卡蒂（Carti）在很长时间就一直在对发行版进行期待，在社交媒体上取笑歌曲，在洛杉矶举办广告牌，似乎随机放下单曲，并在现场表演中首次亮相新曲目，包括本月早些时候的Rolling大声。这一切都是根据计划的。 Carti的经理，Ofium Records总裁兼首席执行官Erin Larsen说：“这总是有点戏弄，从未完全宣布，直到我们终于宣布新专辑正在播放之前，让粉丝参与其中。”而现在，随着音乐准备成为卡蒂职业生涯最大的发行，拉尔森（Larsen）赢得了Billboard本周高管的头衔。

在这里，拉尔森（Larsen）打破了推出音乐背后的一些策略，以及团队如何帮助对专辑的期望进行预期。 “卡蒂是一个完美主义者，”拉尔森解释说。 “他想花时间构建音乐和周围的音乐，并真正为专辑开发声音。”

本周，Playboi Carti发行了他的最新专辑音乐，成为2025年Spotify一天中最流行的专辑，并可能导致了他在Billboard 200上的第二张专辑。您做出了什么关键决定来帮助实现这一目标？

我们的预发行活动始于2023年，这是他第一次在Instagram上透露了第一首歌的“ I Am Music”徽标。我们专注于在整个较长的竞选期间的一致品牌上，并创造了不同的时刻，这些时刻像NBA球衣一样，“我是音乐”，“我是音乐”，关键的新闻界，在现场表演中戏弄唱片等。总是有点挑逗，从不完全宣布，并且从未完全宣布，让粉丝们参与其中，直到我们最终宣布新专辑宣布了新专辑。

有关的

Playboi Carti在头条新闻表演中带来了周末的演出

03/17/2025

这是Carti近五年来的第一张专辑。为什么要在项目中存在差距？您认为项目之间的延长时间对最终发布的期望有什么影响？

卡蒂是一个完美主义者。他想花时间建立周围的音乐和世界，并真正为专辑开发声音。音乐是他创造性愿景的更大代表，我认为他提供的每个项目都不同。当粉丝们想知道他将在这张专辑中走什么方向时，他仍然处于谈话的最前沿，我们试图在途中创造时刻，以将他们带入这一过程。

Carti一直以各种不同的方式嘲笑这个项目的歌曲，仅将视频发布到社交媒体上，在演出中表演未发行的歌曲，并无处不在。该策略如何帮助最终发布该项目？

这感觉就像是关于如何播放音乐的创新方法。我们没有玩片段。我们在YouTube或Instagram上放下了一首歌，粉丝们挖掘了这些平台以听听它们，因为它们在DSP上没有可用。在此过程中，他围绕专辑的声音建立了炒作，我们能够看到哪些曲目真正引起了人们的共鸣。该策略确实打开了对话，使粉丝们感觉就像是过程的一部分。

经过如此延长的等待，以及一系列的广告牌帮助播种了面包屑，Carti宣布了该项目的发布日期。你们为什么认为这是宣布它的最佳方法？

“我是音乐”品牌在推广中变得如此不可或缺，因为它是即将到来的Carti时刻的代名词。我们建立了期待，并继续创造时刻，以使粉丝俘虏并在整个推出过程中参与其中。我认为这种方法也吸引了新粉丝。

有关的

Playboi Carti的“音乐”专辑排名：评论家的精选

03/14/2025

您如何以这种动力前进的Carti发展？

我们将继续提高对项目的认识，以战略时刻构建歌曲，并继续吸引核心粉丝。他的音乐总是充满活力的生活，并使他的愿景栩栩如生，因此巡回演出将产生影响。我们在Interscope拥有出色的合作伙伴，并将与他们合作，将音乐暴露于不同的观众，在广播中建立唱片，使用数字营销和社交以及品牌机会。

是什么在2025年为艺术家带来了针头？

除了出色的音乐之外，我会说真实性，建立一个强大的品牌并找到一种与观众有机联系的方法。

; 1235928349 哈德逊·威斯布鲁克（Hudson Westbrook）如何让听众参加“再次成为房屋”的寂寞之旅https://www.billboard.com/music/country/hudson-westbrook-makin-tracks-house-again-1235928022/Jessica Nicholson Fri, 21 Mar 2025 15:12:37 +0000 CountryMusicgenre countryhttps://www.billboard.com/?p=1235928022 Billboard looks at the writing and recording process behind Hudson Westbrook's "House Again."

当新来的哈德逊·威斯布鲁克（Hudson Westbrook）闯入“又一次”的合唱时，他的第一首单曲晋升为乡村广播，他在四个油腻的音节中画了“现在的ow-ow”一词。

他允许“不是，最正常的方法。”

In fact, the line wasn't written that way originally, but stretching the word creates an extra melodic effect and makes it linger, like the woman that the singer can't get out of his mind. It fits the song's images nicely, the word hanging around — just like her memory — haunting the hallways where every moment of lonely he “now” experiences seems to last forever.

That “now-ow-ow-ow” twist may be a defining moment in Westbrook's growth. Just 20 years old, the former Texas Tech student has only been playing guitar for four years and writing songs for two, so he's still figuring out who he wants to be as an artist and musician. But retooling that one key word in the chorus shows his ability to personalize a piece of music and bring out its central meaning.

“Hudson likes to sit with songs,” says “House Again” co-writer Neil Medley (“Made for You,” “Hung Up On You”), who has penned about a dozen songs with Westbrook. “What I get back from him that we've written is always a little different, but it always falls right into what Hudson does best. I think if he were a video game, he unlocked a skill that day of knowing how to [tap into] his artistry. That was his voice that did that, and he made it so hooky.”

Neither Medley nor co-writer Dan Alley (“Country Song Came On”) knew Westbrook when they wrote with him for the first time on June 4, 2024, at the River House office in Nashville, where all three were signed.

“To be honest,” Alley says, “I had never heard of Hudson.”

Uncertain what to expect, Alley and Medley went through possible topics in a phone call the night before, though it turned out they didn't need them.

“Hudson came in hot with probably five or six just really solid ideas right off the bat and blew me away,” Alley recalls. “One of them was basically the concept of a girl turning a house into a home. [We were] building a story around that, whether it was going to be positive, whether it was going to be negative.”
Medley and Alley had both written songs before using a house-and-home foundation, so they dug in, looking for a different angle they could explore.

“I said, 'Well, I want to write a song about a home that turned into a house again,' ” Westbrook says. “They were like, 'Well, that's the hook.' Honestly, I didn't even know if the idea was writable.”

As Westbrook does routinely, they wrote it in chronological order from the first line.

“You got to set the scene before you sing about the scene,” he reasons.

They started with an image, “This kitchen used to be a dancehall,” that introduced the household theme while incorporating his Lone Star roots. Westbrook leaned emotionally on his parents' divorce, inserting himself into a situation he had witnessed at age 7. Similarly to George Jones' “The Grand Tour,” the song proceeded through the house, with nods to the bedroom, the window and the front door, each of them triggering some thought of the woman who no longer resided there. Medley concocted a video in his mind that helped capture the mood.

“I'm walking through these rooms in my head, and I can see what's missing, what she left behind that used to mean something,” Medley recalls. “Everything we were trying — maybe not 'Doorbell don't ring,' but the porch swing, the kitchen where they're dancing together — we wanted to, for the most part, try to connect it with them as a couple.”

The lyrics played out primarily as a narration until the end of the second verse, when the singer finally lets loose with “What the hell did you do?” almost like a primal scream.

“It's the primal 'I'm screwed,' ” Westbrook notes. “It's the first time in the song that you really hear a point of anger.”

The whole process took place with strummed acoustic guitars ringing underneath.

“We kind of let Hudson run with whatever melody was in his head and didn't try to really get in the way of that,” Alley says. “He's just a very organic artist, and he loves to sing. He was singing a lot in the room, and everything was just kind of sticking.”

They recorded a very basic work tape; neither Alley nor Medley had a clue that day if Westbrook actually liked “House Again.” Westbrook didn't know either, though he played with it periodically in the weeks afterward. He slowed it down about 10 beats per minute, and in the new tempo, that “now” lyric at the start of the chorus practically begged to get stretched out.

In September, he cut “House Again” at The Amber Sound, a homey studio in Nashville's Hermitage neighborhood co-owned by producer Ryan Youmans (Muscadine Bloodline, Luke Grimes). They cast it sonically like Keith Urban's “Blue Ain't Your Color,” using bluesy triplets in tandem with a Hammond B-3 and a gritty electric guitar. Youmans revised a major chord near the end of the chorus as a minor one, heightening the self-pity in the text.

A day later, Westbrook returned to River House to do the final vocal with co-producer Lukas Scott (Austin Snell, David J). Scott used the room's ambient side lighting to give the place a darker atmosphere, and Westbrook sang it like he meant it. The performance had some small quirks — he sings “pillow,” for example, as “pellow” — but those enhanced his authenticity.

“He does have unique little inflections and ways that he sings things, and sometimes, if he tries to change it, I tell him, 'Don't,' ” Scott says. “His voice has so much character in the way that he sings those words.”

They got Kaylin Roberson to sing harmonies, allowing the song to subliminally hint at the woman who's still inhabiting the singer's mind, even if she's no longer in his house.

“When you hear the female vocal and his vocal,” Scott says, “it can almost feel like there's potentially a girl singing, and thinking the same thing.”

Westbrook thought initially that the song was too personal to appeal to anyone else, but River House vp/GM Zebb Luster suggested he might be overthinking it. The label released “House Again” to digital streaming partners on Oct. 18. It has rolled up more than 45 million streams since on Spotify alone, leading to a deal with Warner Music Nashville, which released it with River House to country radio via PlayMPE on Feb. 24. It debuted at No. 57 on the Country Airplay chart dated March 22. It's at No. 31 on the multimetric Hot Country Songs list in its 19th charted week, creating a welcome dichotomy in his concerts.

“It did help get some stuff off my chest, and I do enjoy singing it with a fistful of anger every single night,” Westbrook says. “But how do you sing with a fistful of anger if you got 3,000 people singing along? You just can't help but smile, so it's been really cool.”

With Rare , her third solo studio album, the former Disney Channel breakthrough-turned multi hyphenate superstar distilled her skills as a recording artist into a slinky, sumptuous dance-pop record, full of self-empowering lyrics and midtempo earworms that understood precisely how to utilize her singular tone. Gomez earned the best reviews of her career; she also scored the first Hot 100 chart-topper, with the still-stunning self-acceptance ballad “Lose You to Love Me.” And she seemingly unlocked exactly the type of pop star she wanted to be.

Following Rare , Gomez moved on to other successful creative endeavors — the smash-hit TV show Only Murders in the Building , the cooking show Selena + Chef , collaborations like Blackpink's “Ice Cream” and a remix of Rema's “Calm Down,” a supporting role in the Oscar-winning Emilia Pérez — in addition to her gigantic business and brand deals. These projects have understandably kept Gomez busy, and although some solo music was unveiled, the next proper album never materialized.

I Said I Love You First is that long-awaited follow-up, and also, it's not. The new album is credited to Gomez and Benny Blanco, her longtime romantic partner and new fiancé who happens to be one of the most prominent pop producers of the past 15 years. Although other producers help mold the album's sound, I Said I Love You First is a creative collaboration between two halves of a shared heart, and Blanco's sonic influence exists in direct conversation with Gomez's lyrical delivery. There's a reason why the album artwork is a glimpse of Gomez and Blanco through a keyhole — I Said I Love You First is presented as an intimate glimpse, not big-budget spectacle.

And yet, the Rare diehards are going to find a lot to embrace here. Gomez is a pop veteran who understands the contours of her voice, and how to imbue a line with emotional wallop. Whether she's reflecting on failed romances of the past or toasting to the life she and Blanco have built together, she remains a nuanced performer who rises to meet the moment in front of her. Whether she's sashaying through a danceable beat or whispering over acoustic haze, Gomez makes the love story that Blanco helped construct on I Said I Love You First accessible to the world, and at long last adds a compelling new entry to her catalog.
